  • jinja2.lexer

jinja2.lexer

Implements a Jinja / Python combination lexer. The Lexer class is used to do some preprocessing. It filters out invalid operators like the bitshift operators we don’t allow in templates. It separates template code and python code in expressions.

Returns a description of the token.

jinja2.lexer.describe_token_expr(expr: str) → str[source]

Like describe_token but for token expressions.

jinja2.lexer.count_newlines(value: str) → int[source]

Count the number of newline characters in the string. This is useful for extensions that filter a stream.

jinja2.lexer.compile_rules(environment: jinja2.environment.Environment) → List[Tuple[str, str]][source]

Compiles all the rules from the environment into a list of rules.

class jinja2.lexer.Failure(message: str, cls: Type[jinja2.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError] = TemplateSyntaxError)[source]

Class that raises a TemplateSyntaxError if called. Used by the Lexer to specify known errors.

class jinja2.lexer.Token[source]

Bases: NamedTuple

lineno: int[source]
type: str[source]
value: str[source]
test(expr: str) → bool[source]

Test a token against a token expression. This can either be a token type or 'token_type:token_value'. This can only test against string values and types.

test_any(*iterable: str) → bool[source]

Test against multiple token expressions.

class jinja2.lexer.TokenStreamIterator(stream: TokenStream)[source]

The iterator for tokenstreams. Iterate over the stream until the eof token is reached.

stream[source]
class jinja2.lexer.TokenStream(generator: Iterable[Token], name: str | None, filename: str | None)[source]

A token stream is an iterable that yields Tokens. The parser however does not iterate over it but calls next() to go one token ahead. The current active token is stored as current.

name[source]
filename[source]
closed = False[source]
current[source]
property eos: bool[source]

Are we at the end of the stream?

push(token: Token) → None[source]

Push a token back to the stream.

look() → Token[source]

Look at the next token.

skip(n: int = 1) → None[source]

Got n tokens ahead.

next_if(expr: str) → Token | None[source]

Perform the token test and return the token if it matched. Otherwise the return value is None.

skip_if(expr: str) → bool[source]

Like next_if() but only returns True or False.

close() → None[source]

Close the stream.

expect(expr: str) → Token[source]

Expect a given token type and return it. This accepts the same argument as jinja2.lexer.Token.test().

jinja2.lexer.get_lexer(environment: jinja2.environment.Environment) → Lexer[source]

Return a lexer which is probably cached.

class jinja2.lexer.OptionalLStrip[source]

Bases: tuple

A special tuple for marking a point in the state that can have lstrip applied.

class jinja2.lexer.Lexer(environment: jinja2.environment.Environment)[source]

Class that implements a lexer for a given environment. Automatically created by the environment class, usually you don’t have to do that.

Note that the lexer is not automatically bound to an environment. Multiple environments can share the same lexer.

lstrip_blocks[source]
newline_sequence[source]
keep_trailing_newline[source]
rules: Dict[str, List[_Rule]][source]
tokenize(source: str, name: str | None = None, filename: str | None = None, state: str | None = None) → TokenStream[source]

Calls tokeniter + tokenize and wraps it in a token stream.

wrap(stream: Iterable[Tuple[int, str, str]], name: str | None = None, filename: str | None = None) → Iterator[Token][source]

This is called with the stream as returned by tokenize and wraps every token in a Token and converts the value.

tokeniter(source: str, name: str | None, filename: str | None = None, state: str | None = None) → Iterator[Tuple[int, str, str]][source]

This method tokenizes the text and returns the tokens in a generator. Use this method if you just want to tokenize a template.

Changed in version 3.0: Only \n, \r\n and \r are treated as line breaks.
